DISCHARGE SUMMARY
**INSTITUTION
**PLACE , PA **ZIP-CODE
**NAME[AAA , BBB M]
**ID-NUM
**ID-NUM
A5A/504
SERVICE OF :
**NAME[ZZZ]
**NAME[YYY]
DATE OF ADMISSION :
**DATE[Feb 26 2007]
DATE OF DISCHARGE :
**DATE[Mar 02 2007]
PRINCIPAL DIAGNOSIS :
Chronic abdominal pain , secondary to recurrent chronic pancreatitis .
SECONDARY DIAGNOSES :
1. Major recurrent depression .
2. Posttraumatic stress disorder .
3. Pancreatic pseudocyst that is resolving on the recent CT of the abdomen .
4. Tobacco abuse .
5. History of alcohol abuse , status post inpatient rehab .
CONSULTANTS :
1. Dr. **NAME[XXX] from the GI Service .
2. Dr. **NAME[WWW] from the Surgery Service .
3. Dr. **NAME[VVV] from Psychiatry .
4. **INSTITUTION .
PROCEDURES :
Upper endoscopy and colonoscopy by Dr. **NAME[UUU] .
For details of history and physical , please refer to the dictated summary by Dr. **NAME[TTT] .
HOSPITAL COURSE :
The patient was treated with IV Dilaudid for management of pain , and his fentanyl patch at 25 mcg / hour was continued .
He was also given IV fluids and kept n.p.o. for the first two days .
Lab work for pancreatitis was ordered and this showed no recurrence .
Repeat CT of the abdomen and pelvis showed an actual improvement in his previous pancreatitis .
The peripancreatic cystic collection had completely resolved when compared to the previous CT scan .
The patient was seen by Dr. **NAME[XXX] , and was further evaluated with upper and lower GI endoscopies which were completely normal except for a small sigmoid polyp that was excised and this was a hyperplastic polyp .
Therefore , he underwent a small - bowel followthrough the following day , which was a completely normal study .
Both the Surgical Service and the GI Service felt that there was a huge functional component to his abdominal pain .
The patient continued to use IV Dilaudid around the clock and after all of the above testing came back normal , I had a long conversation with the patient and he was made aware of the fact that he needs to address his depression and anxiety problems with regular followup with a psychiatrist , and the Dilaudid was tapered and discontinued within 48 hours .
He was treated with p.r.n.
Percocet , and he did quite well .
Of note , throughout his entire stay whenever the patient was allowed to eat , he ate regular meals and had no symptoms of nausea , vomiting , or bowel habit changes .
CONDITION AT THE TIME OF DISCHARGE :
The patient was clinically stable , although he continued to complain of abdominal pain .
Minimal tenderness was noted in the epigastric region .
DISPOSITION :
The patient was discharged to home with home care consult .
DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS :
1. Klonopin 1 mg , three times a day .
2. Zoloft 100 mg twice a day .
3. Fentanyl patch 25 mcg per hour q.3 day application .
4. Percocet 5/325 one tablet q.4 hours to q.6 hours p.r.n.
5. Nicotine patch 14 mg per 24 - hour daily application .
6. Prilosec 20 mg daily .
DIET :
The patient was advised to avoid greasy foods and to absolutely stay sober and avoid alcoholic beverages .
FOLLOWUP CARE :
1. The patient is to see Dr. **NAME[YYY] in 2 to 3 weeks at the **INSTITUTION Harmar office and call **PHONE for an appointment .
2. To see Dr. **NAME[SSS] in 4 to 5 weeks at the **STREET-ADDRESS. **NAME[RRR] office .
3. Home social service has been arranged for outpatient psychiatric followup , as the patient presently has appointments with a psychiatrist in Greentree and the patient lives in Cheswick and he frequently misses his appointments .
It is imperative that the patient have regular psychiatric followup .
On the day of discharge , I discussed in great detail about the pain medications and the need to gradually taper and discontinue them over the next 1 to 2 months .
The patient is made aware that all of his narcotic prescriptions will be given by me , and he is to regularly followup in the office as advised .
The patient acknowledged understanding .
Time spent on discharge day management and discussion with the patient is **AGE[in 30s] minutes .
___________________
**NAME[ZZZ YYY] , M.D.
